38 def filter_points(path, points, grid_dim):
39  # for each point in 'points', return only points within boundaries
40  x = points[:,0]
41  y = points[:,1]
42  thresh = points[ (grid_dim[0] <= x)*(x <= grid_dim[1])* (grid_dim[2] <= y)*(y <= grid_dim[3])]
43  return thresh
44 
45 def init_grid(grid_dim, grid_size, init_val):
46  # Add 1 to even out world coordinates
47  # Add np ceil to ensure actual grid size is not bigger than desired
48  # since for some values, the grid dim wont divide evenly by grid size
49  xvals = int(np.ceil((grid_dim[1] - grid_dim[0] + 1) / grid_size))
50  yvals = int(np.ceil((grid_dim[3] - grid_dim[2] + 1) / grid_size))
51  if init_val != 0:
52  return init_val * np.ones((yvals, xvals))
53  else:
54  return np.zeros((yvals, xvals))
55 
56 
57 def get_index(x, y, grid_size, grid_dim):
58  # Convert from world coordinates to index
59  #indx = int((x - grid_dim[0])/grid_size)
60  #indy = int((y - grid_dim[2])/grid_size)
61  # Make sure x,y fall within the grid physical boundaries
62  if np.any((grid_dim[0] <= x) *
63  (x <= grid_dim[1]) == 0) and np.any((grid_dim[2] <= y) *
64  (y <= grid_dim[3]) == 0):
65  raise NameError('(x,y) world coordinates must be within boundaries')
66  indx = np.round((x - grid_dim[0]) / grid_size).astype(int)
67  indy = np.round((y - grid_dim[2]) / grid_size).astype(int)
68  return (indx, indy)
69 
70 
71 # A list of all the points in our grid
72 def mesh_grid_list(grid_dim, grid_size):
73  # Make a mesh grid with the specified grid size/dim
74  xvals = np.arange(grid_dim[0], grid_dim[1], grid_size)
75  yvals = np.arange(grid_dim[2], grid_dim[3], grid_size)
76  x, y = np.meshgrid(xvals, yvals)
77  x, y = x.flatten(), y.flatten()
78  points = np.vstack((x,y)).T
79  return points
80 
81 def get_world(indx, indy, grid_size, grid_dim):
82  # Convert from index to world coordinates
83  x = (indx) * grid_size + grid_dim[0]
84  y = (indy) * grid_size + grid_dim[2]
85  return (x, y)
86 
87 ''' courtesty of https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42463172/how-to-perform-max-mean-pooling-on-a-2d-array-using-numpy'''
88 
89 def pooling(mat,ksize,method='max',pad=False):
90  '''Non-overlapping pooling on 2D or 3D data.
91 
92  <mat>: ndarray, input array to pool.
93  <ksize>: tuple of 2, kernel size in (ky, kx).
94  <method>: str, 'max for max-pooling,
95  'mean' for mean-pooling.
96  <pad>: bool, pad <mat> or not. If no pad, output has size
97  n//f, n being <mat> size, f being kernel size.
98  if pad, output has size ceil(n/f).
99 
100  Return <result>: pooled matrix.
101  '''
102 
103  m, n = mat.shape[:2]
104  ky,kx=ksize
105 
106  _ceil=lambda x,y: int(np.ceil(x/float(y)))
107 
108  if pad:
109  ny=_ceil(m,ky)
110  nx=_ceil(n,kx)
111  size=(ny*ky, nx*kx)+mat.shape[2:]
112  mat_pad=np.full(size,np.nan)
113  mat_pad[:m,:n,...]=mat
114  else:
115  ny=m//ky
116  nx=n//kx
117  mat_pad=mat[:ny*ky, :nx*kx, ...]
118 
119  new_shape=(ny,ky,nx,kx)+mat.shape[2:]
120 
121  if method=='max':
122  result=np.nanmax(mat_pad.reshape(new_shape),axis=(1,3))
123  else:
124  result=np.nanmean(mat_pad.reshape(new_shape),axis=(1,3))
125 
126  return result
